title: When writing a novel, is it ok to name a main character after yourself? - Quora

response.answer_text: Okay, I wasn’t planning on writing an answer to this question since I saw that there was already 30 of them, but I skimmed through them, and none of them said what I’m about to say. Technically, yes, it’s your story and it’s perfectly fine to do what you will with it. If that means naming a main character after yourself, go for it—this is especially okay if you’re writing an autobiography, memoir, or some other piece of non-fiction involving yourself. In practice, however, naming a main character after yourself may not be the wisest thing. Some of the other answers have already hit on this, so I won’t go too much into detail, but if you’re naming a main character specifically after yourself—not just giving it the same name—you’ll likely hold a certain fondness for the character and will therefore be particularly up in arms if someone were to critique him or her. However, there’s more than just that reason for opting to name your character literally anything that isn’t your name. When I see a book in the fiction section, and I see the author’s name of that book on the cover of it, and inside the cover jacket, I see that the main character’s name is that of the author, I tend to cringe. There’s something naive about naming a main character after yourself, something that suggests that a vulnerability nobody asked to be there is present. Furthermore, when I see that an author has named his character after himself, I put the book down, because, to me at least, it suggests a lack of creativity, and in that book I would expect to find the author building himself up, trying to take away all of the flaws he has to make himself as perfect as possible, and a character without flaws is boring and not relatable. That’s how I see it, at least. Overall, my advice to you would be to write whatever story you want to write, but if you can, I’d definitely consider giving your main character a name that is not yours.

There’s no rule that says you can’t name a main character after yourself. If you’re writing a novel, the predicament comes from people assuming that you are talking about yourself. More importantly, people will most likely think that the character traits, mannerisms, behaviors, habits, and actions described in the book are yours. It’s one thing if it is, and you’re fine with your readers knowing that about you. However, if you create a character with your name that has different traits and performs actions that are contradictory to how you really are, and people are going to confuse the character from you, then I would consider whether that could have an unintended effect. As a guideline, I don’t use my or anyone’s full names I know in a fictional novel because it becomes problematic later. If you’re writing non-fiction, then so be it. But you really should look to use different names when creating a fictional universe.
